Award.AwardTitle: Rnf: A New Class of Redox-coupled Ion Transporters

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit
Considerable diversity exists in the mechanisms of ion transport in living systems. This is basic research into one class of ion transport proteins that is widely distributed in the biosphere. Rnf is a widely distributed family of bacterial membrane proteins that is involved in a variety of important physiological processes, including nitrogen fixation, oxygen sensing and anaerobic metabolism. So far, all the members of this family seem to transport sodium ions across the bacterial cell membrane. Some Rnfs behave as redox-driven ion pumps contributing energy to the membrane potential, while others consume the gradient to drive unfavorable redox reactions. Moreover, the actual directionality of coupling between the redox reaction and ion translocation appears to vary in different Rnfs. For a class of enzymes with so many important roles, little is known about the structure or mechanism. The overall goal of this project is to define the physiological roles of the various Rnfs and understand the mechanisms that underpin these functions. Efforts will be focused on the identity of the pumped ion, the directionality of the pumping reaction, the topology of the enzyme and the localization of cofactors with respect to the membrane. This work will provide the basis for future studies on members of this family and will shed light of how similar proteins perform diverse functions. The project will use a combination of biophysical, kinetic and spectroscopic studies using site directed mutants to characterize the individual mechanistic steps in the enzyme reaction. This multidisciplinary approach will give an understanding of the functioning of this family of proteins in the context of the overall bacterial physiology.

Broader Impact
This project will provide a foundation for the understanding of the mechanism of the Rnf family of proteins, a group of proteins widely distributed in bacteria. The combination of biochemistry, biophysical techniques will provide a better understanding of the mechanism of these enzymes, their physiological roles and eventually how bacteria achieve complicated reactions as nitrogen fixation, oxygen sensing and adaptation to different environments.

The PI is actively involved in graduate and undergraduate education and students at all levels participate in research efforts in the PI's laboratory. This project will include a strong commitment in training a graduate student and a postdoctoral trainee in the PI's lab. The multidisciplinary approach of the project will provide an excellent opportunity for the participants of this project to learn basic techniques in Microbiology, Biochemistry, Spectroscopy and Biophysics. The laboratory will host a summer student from the local High School in coordination with the 'Design your Future Day Program' which brings high school girls to visit RPI for a day.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has supported our ongoing studies of an important, and little-understood enzyme complex found only in bacteria and archaea, known as RNF. RNF is an ion pump that facilitates the transfer of energy between metabolic intermediate compounds and the bacterial membrane gradient. RNF is related to the respiratory enzyme NQR and is similar in many respects, but it is believed to have a much wider range of biological functions, including 1) producing the crucial intermediate NADH, for example in conditions, where oxygen is not present, 2) pumping Na+ out of the cell, which maintains internal conditions hospitable for life and 3) providing energy to other membrane proteins and 4) supplying the voltage required to keep the oxygen sensing system, SoxR, in its active state.

RNF is an integral enzyme in the cell membrane, comprised of 6 protein subunits as well as some electron carrying cofactors. RNF is believed to carry out different functions in various microorganisms, and so as a first step, we cloned the operons containing the genes for RNF from several different bacteria, including Rhodobacter sphaeroides (a photosynthetic organism), Escherichia coli, Vibrio cholerae and recently Bacteroides fragilis, and were able to express them as proteins.  Using the enzyme from Bacteroides fragilis, we demonstrated that the activity of the complex links together the reduction of ferredoxin, the oxidation of NADH and the translocation of Na+ ions.

 

We used a combination of genetic and spectroscopic methods to identify cofactors in the enzyme and localize them to the various subunits of the complex. We also recently established that riboflavin is a cofactor in RNF. The only enzyme previously known to contain riboflavin as a cofactor was the related NQR.  By genetically creating fusions between RNF and “reporter” proteins, which show different properties depending on whether they are inside or outside of the cell, together with computer models, we defined the orientation of all the transmembrane alpha-helices of the complex respect to the membrane as well as important negatively charged amino acids that are likely to be key groups for ion translocation. Interestingly, this topological map of RNF matches that in the recently published crystallographic model of NQR

 

This grant has made it possible for my laboratory to train several students, including high students, undergraduates, doctoral students, and a postdoctoral scientist. During this time, we also actively participated in two programs: “Design your future day,” which brings female high school students to RPI. The students were involved in experiments related to this project which introduced them to basic Microbiology, Molecular Biology, and Biochemistry techniques.

The results obtained in this grant have been presented in seminars at RPI and other institutions. These seminars have been for professional scientists, and also for undergraduates and high school students.
